title: On certain extremal Banach-Mazur distances in small dimensions
abstract:
We study the maximal possible Banach-Mazur distance for certain pairs of
symmetric convex bodies. A classical consequence of the John Ellipsoid Theorem
is that the Banach-Mazur distance of a symmetric convex body $K \subseteq
\mathbb{R}^n$ to the $n$-dimensional Euclidean ball is not greater than
$\sqrt{n}$. Equality holds in every dimension $n$ for the unit balls of
$\ell_1^n$ and $\ell_{\infty}^n$, that is, for cross-polytopes and
parallelotopes in dimension $n$. While it is known that in dimension $n \geq
4$, there are more convex bodies (not affinely equivalent to either of the
previous two) with the distance $\sqrt{n}$ to the ball, and that for $n=2$ the
parallelogram is unique, the characterization of the equality case for
dimension $n=3$ seems to have never been published. We prove that the
three-dimensional cross-polytopes and parallelotopes are the only symmetric
convex bodies in $\mathbb{R}^3$ with the distance $\sqrt{3}$ to the Euclidean
ball. Moreover, in the planar case we establish the stability of the uniqueness
of the parallelogram with the best possible (linear) order of the estimate. We
also consider the maximal possible Banach-Mazur distance between planar
$1$-symmetric convex bodies. In this case, we prove that the maximal possible
distance is $\sqrt{2}$ and characterize the equality case, which again involves
a parallelogram.
